trans-unit.source: Create a Node.js web app in Azure App Service | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create a Node.js web app in Azure App Service | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to build and deploy a Node.js web app in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to build and deploy a Node.js web app in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Build and deploy a Node.js web app in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Build and deploy a Node.js web app in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to create a <link><linkText>Node[nodejs.org]</linkText><title></title></link> application and deploy it to the <link><linkText>Web Apps feature in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> by using [Git].
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to create a <link><linkText>Node[nodejs.org]</linkText><title></title></link> application and deploy it to the <link><linkText>Web Apps feature in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> by using [Git].

trans-unit.source: The instructions in this tutorial can be followed on any operating system that is capable of running Node.
trans-unit.target: The instructions in this tutorial can be followed on any operating system that is capable of running Node.

trans-unit.source: A screenshot of the completed application is below:
trans-unit.target: A screenshot of the completed application is below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>A browser displaying the 'Hello World' message.</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>A browser displaying the 'Hello World' message.</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Create a web app and enable Git publishing
trans-unit.target: Create a web app and enable Git publishing

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to create a web app and enable Git publishing.
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to create a web app and enable Git publishing.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need a Microsoft Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can <link><linkText>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>sign up for a free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can <link><linkText>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>sign up for a free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the <link><linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click the + NEW icon on the top left of the portal.
trans-unit.target: Click the + NEW icon on the top left of the portal.

trans-unit.source: Click Web + Mobile, and then click Web app.
trans-unit.target: Click Web + Mobile, and then click Web app.

trans-unit.source: Enter a value for URL.
trans-unit.target: Enter a value for URL.

trans-unit.source: Select an App Service plan or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Select an App Service plan or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: If you create a new plan, select the pricing tier, location, and other options.
trans-unit.target: If you create a new plan, select the pricing tier, location, and other options.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: Once the status changes to Running, the portal automatically opens the blade for your web app.
trans-unit.target: Once the status changes to Running, the portal automatically opens the blade for your web app.

trans-unit.source: You can also reach the blade by clicking Browse.
trans-unit.target: You can also reach the blade by clicking Browse.

trans-unit.source: Click Deployment.
trans-unit.target: Click Deployment.

trans-unit.source: You may need to scroll to see this part of the blade.
trans-unit.target: You may need to scroll to see this part of the blade.

trans-unit.source: Click Choose Source, click Local Git Repository, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click Choose Source, click Local Git Repository, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Click the deployment credentials part (outlined in red below).
trans-unit.target: Click the deployment credentials part (outlined in red below).

trans-unit.source: Create a user name and password.
trans-unit.target: Create a user name and password.

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: If you previously enabled publishing for a web app, you don't need to do this step.
trans-unit.target: If you previously enabled publishing for a web app, you don't need to do this step.

trans-unit.source: To publish, you will push to a Git remote repository.
trans-unit.target: To publish, you will push to a Git remote repository.

trans-unit.source: Find the URL for the repository, click All Settings, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: Find the URL for the repository, click All Settings, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: The URL is listed under GIT URL.
trans-unit.target: The URL is listed under GIT URL.

trans-unit.source: Build and test your application locally
trans-unit.target: Build and test your application locally

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will create a server.js file that contains the 'Hello World' example from [nodejs.org].
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will create a server.js file that contains the 'Hello World' example from [nodejs.org].

trans-unit.source: This example has been modified from the original example by adding process.env.PORT as the port to listen on when running in an Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: This example has been modified from the original example by adding process.env.PORT as the port to listen on when running in an Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: By using a text editor, create a new file named server.js in the helloworld directory.
trans-unit.target: By using a text editor, create a new file named server.js in the helloworld directory.

trans-unit.source: If the helloworld directory does not exist, create it.
trans-unit.target: If the helloworld directory does not exist, create it.

trans-unit.source: Add the following as the contents of the server.js file, and then save it:
trans-unit.target: Add the following as the contents of the server.js file, and then save it:

trans-unit.source: Open the command line, and use the following command to start the web app locally:
trans-unit.target: Open the command line, and use the following command to start the web app locally:

trans-unit.source: Open your web browser and navigate to http://localhost:1337.
trans-unit.target: Open your web browser and navigate to http://localhost:1337.

trans-unit.source: A webpage that displays "Hello World" will appear, as shown in the screenshot below:
trans-unit.target: A webpage that displays "Hello World" will appear, as shown in the screenshot below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>A browser displaying the 'Hello World' message.</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>A browser displaying the 'Hello World' message.</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Publish your application
trans-unit.target: Publish your application

trans-unit.source: From the command line, change directories to the helloworld directory and enter the following command to initialize a local Git repository.
trans-unit.target: From the command line, change directories to the helloworld directory and enter the following command to initialize a local Git repository.

trans-unit.source: Is the Git command unavailable?
trans-unit.target: Is the Git command unavailable?

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Git</linkText><title></title></link> is a distributed version-control system that you can use to deploy your Azure website.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Git</linkText><title></title></link> is a distributed version-control system that you can use to deploy your Azure website.

trans-unit.source: For installation instructions for your platform, see the <link><linkText>Git download page</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For installation instructions for your platform, see the <link><linkText>Git download page</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Use the following commands to add files to the repository:
trans-unit.target: Use the following commands to add files to the repository:

trans-unit.source: Add a Git remote for pushing updates to the web app that you created previously, by using the following command:
trans-unit.target: Add a Git remote for pushing updates to the web app that you created previously, by using the following command:

trans-unit.source: Push your changes to Azure by using the following command:
trans-unit.target: Push your changes to Azure by using the following command:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted for the password that you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted for the password that you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: The output should be similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: The output should be similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: To view your app, click the Browse button on the Web App part within the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: To view your app, click the Browse button on the Web App part within the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Publish changes to your application
trans-unit.target: Publish changes to your application

trans-unit.source: Open the server.js file in a text editor, and change 'Hello World\n' to 'Hello Azure\n'.
trans-unit.target: Open the server.js file in a text editor, and change 'Hello World\n' to 'Hello Azure\n'.

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: From the command line, change directories to the helloworld directory and run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: From the command line, change directories to the helloworld directory and run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted for the password that you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted for the password that you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Browse to your app by clicking Browse, and note that the updates have been applied.
trans-unit.target: Browse to your app by clicking Browse, and note that the updates have been applied.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>A web page displaying 'Hello Azure'</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>A web page displaying 'Hello Azure'</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can revert to the previous deployment by selecting it in Deployments.
trans-unit.target: You can revert to the previous deployment by selecting it in Deployments.

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before you sign up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before you sign up for an Azure account, go to <link><linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: There, you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service—no credit card required, and no commitments.
trans-unit.target: There, you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service—no credit card required, and no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: While the steps in this article use the Azure portal to create a web app, you can also use the <link><linkText>Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText><title></title></link> to perform the same operations.
trans-unit.target: While the steps in this article use the Azure portal to create a web app, you can also use the <link><linkText>Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText><title></title></link> to perform the same operations.

trans-unit.source: Node.js provides a rich ecosystem of modules that can be used by your applications.
trans-unit.target: Node.js provides a rich ecosystem of modules that can be used by your applications.

trans-unit.source: To learn how Web Apps works with modules, see <link><linkText>Using Node.js modules with Azure applications</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how Web Apps works with modules, see <link><linkText>Using Node.js modules with Azure applications</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the versions of Node.js that are provided with Azure and how to specify the version to be used with your application, see <link><linkText>Specifying a Node.js version in an Azure application</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the versions of Node.js that are provided with Azure and how to specify the version to be used with your application, see <link><linkText>Specifying a Node.js version in an Azure application</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you encounter problems with your application after it has been deployed to Azure, see <link><linkText>How to debug a Node.js application in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> for information on diagnosing the problem.
trans-unit.target: If you encounter problems with your application after it has been deployed to Azure, see <link><linkText>How to debug a Node.js application in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link> for information on diagnosing the problem.

trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service, see <link><linkText>Azure App Service and existing Azure services</linkText><title></title></link>.
